parameterdescription.para: The polar interpolator to interpolate the function once the characteristics have been computed.
An IFootFinder which computes the feet of the characteristics.
The mapping function from the logical domain to the physical domain.

memberdef.definition: BslAdvectionPolar< FootFinder, LogicalToPhysicalMapping, InterpolatorPolar >::~BslAdvectionPolar
memberdef.name: ~BslAdvectionPolar

memberdef.name: operator()

briefdescription.para: Advect a function over a time step dt with the given advection field along the physical directions.

parameterdescription.para: A Field containing the values of the function we want to advect.
A field of vectors defined on the Cartesian basis containing the values of the advection field at each point on the logical grid.

simplesect.para: A Field to allfdistribu advected on the time step given.

memberdef.definition: DFieldFDistribu BslAdvectionPolar< FootFinder, LogicalToPhysicalMapping, InterpolatorPolar >::operator()
memberdef.argsstring: (DFieldFDistribu allfdistribu, DVectorConstFieldAdvectionRTheta advection_field_rtheta, DTensor< CartesianBasis > const &advection_field_xy_centre, double dt) const
memberdef.name: operator()

briefdescription.para: Advect a function over a time step dt with the given advection field along the logical directions and physical directions for the O-point.

simplesect.para: This operator should be applied if the O-point corresponds to points of the grid.

parameterdescription.para: A Field containing the values of the function we want to advect.
A field of vectors defined on the Curvilinear basis containing the values of the advection field at each point on the logical grid. It is expressed on the contravariant basis.
A vector in the Cartesian basis, containing the value of the advection field at the O-point.

simplesect.para: A Field to allfdistribu advected on the time step given.

memberdef.definition: DFieldFDistribu BslAdvectionPolar< FootFinder, LogicalToPhysicalMapping, InterpolatorPolar >::operator()
memberdef.argsstring: (DFieldFDistribu allfdistribu, DVectorConstFieldAdvectionRTheta advection_field_rtheta, double dt) const
memberdef.name: operator()

briefdescription.para: Advect a function over a time step dt with the given advection field along the logical directions. It builds the advection field along the physical directions at the O-point though averaged values on the first ring.

detaileddescription.para: The value at the O-point of the given advection field is not used here. We compute the advection field on the physical axis at the O-point by averaging its values at the next interpolation point along r.

parameterdescription.para: A Field containing the values of the function we want to advect.
A field of vectors defined on the Curvilinear basis containing the values of the advection field at each point on the logical grid. It is expressed on the contravariant basis.

simplesect.para: A Field to allfdistribu advected on the time step given.

briefdescription.para: Define an advection operator on 2D $(r, \theta)$ domain.

detaileddescription.para: The advection operator uses a backward semi-Lagrangian method. The method is based on the property that the solution is constant along the characteristics.
For the following equation: $\partial_t f(t,x) + A(t, x) \cdot \nabla_x f(t,x) = 0, $
we write the characteristics: $ \partial_t X(t; s, x) = A(t, X(t; s, x)), \qquad \text{ with } X(s; s, x) = x. $
Then the property gives us: $ f(t, x) = f(0, X(t; 0, x)), \quad \forall t. $
So the first step of the advection operator is to compute the feet of the characteristics $ X(t; t+\Delta t, x_i) $ for each mesh point $ x_i $.
For the second step, we interpolate the function at the computed feet of the characteristics, and obtain the function at the next time step: $ f(t + \Delta t, x) = f(t, X(t; t+\Delta, x))$.
Different time integration methods are implemented to solve the equation of the characteristics. They are defined in the IPolarFootFinder class.
The feet can be advected on different domains (physical domain or pseudo-physical domain) which are determined in the SplinePolarFootFinder operator.
The interpolation of the function is always done in the logical domain, where the B-splines are defined.
